Award.AwardTitle: NEESR Planning/Collaborative Research: Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects (LEAP) for Validation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objective of this planning project is to lay the groundwork and to conduct preliminary research and preparation activities for a subsequent NEESR2 proposal to produce a high quality experimental data, as well as validate and develop confidence in the computational tools used for liquefaction analysis. The ultimate goal of the project is to advance the current understanding and computational predictive capabilities of the liquefaction phenomenon and its consequences on civil infrastructure systems through integrated centrifuge experiments and numerical simulations. The essential elements of this planning project consist of: a) a planning workshop to identify a group of boundary value problems and the material(s) of choice (e.g., type of sand) in the subsequent centrifuge tests of the NEESR2 project, b) an extensive and careful review and compilation of the experimental data available in the NEEShub and other relevant databases, c) preliminary class-C numerical simulations to begin the process of assessing the modeling capabilities currently available in the research community and geotechnical practice, d) design of a series of centrifuge tests that simulate a set of boundary value problems of interest to geotechnical practice with an increasing order of complexity, e) a prediction exercise symposium that leverages the results of the centrifuge tests that will be conducted by our international collaborators in the UK, Japan, and China, and f) development of validation metrics, tools, and protocols to assess the reliability of computational models.

This planning project and the follow-on NEESR2 project will provide high quality validation data that will reduce the need for certain routine experiments and hence allow more resources to be used on experiments that explore new features of soil behavior. In turn, validated numerical modeling techniques and high confidence in their predictive capabilities will reduce the dependence of the profession on large scale costly experiments. The project will provide a rare opportunity for collaboration with the international community on a research topic that is of critical value to the international geotechnical engineering community. Three graduate students will participate in the project and will be trained in physical and numerical modeling of liquefiable soils. The three institutions will continue and build on their current outreach efforts to attract members of under-represented groups to participate in the project as graduate students. The project will establish an experimental dataset and a formal protocol for validation of our simulation tools to fully elucidate their capabilities and limitations. These capabilities and limitations are essential for intelligent management and maintenance of our infrastructure. Data from this project will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES data repository. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
P-LEAP (Planning for Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects) laid the ground to establish an international collaboration for a subsequent series of validation exercises of soil liquefaction models and simulation tools. Liquefaction of saturated sandy soil deposits is a pervasive and costly problem during earthquakes. It is a phenomenon that leads to loss of stiffness and strength and can cause catastrophic damage to infrastructure such as bridges, buildings and ports. There have been major advances in development of computational tools for predicting the triggering and consequences of liquefaction, but these tools have not yet been adequately validated. A preliminary validation effort (referred to as LEAP-GWU-2015) was undertaken using the liquefaction test results of a benchmark prototype that was modeled experimentally at six centrifuge facilities, namely Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), University of California, Davis (UCD), Cambridge University (CU), Kyoto University (KU), Taiwan National Central University (NCU), and Zhejiang University (ZJU). A simplified earthquake motion (a tapered sinusoidal input base acceleration) was prescribed as a target for all the conducted tests. The centrifuge facilities were able to match the target motion with a varying degree of accuracy. The variations in input motions, along with other dissimilarities in initial conditions, led to some differences in experimental results (e.g., accelerations, displacements and pore water pressures).  Nevertheless, the observed response provides overall good quality data for validation. To assess the capabilities of a few prominent constitutive models and numerical simulation tools for soil liquefaction analysis, a series of blind predictions were undertaken at Virginia Tech, the University of Washington, California State University, Sacramento, and by practitioners in the USA and Japan. The predictions provided valuable information on the capabilities of the employed models, particularly with respect to the estimation of liquefaction-induced deformations.  The results of LEAP-GWU-2015 accentuated the needs for a comprehensive assessment of experiment repeatability and sensitivity and also for validation metrics to quantitatively assess experimental results and numerical predictions. These issues are currently being investigated by the ensuing (ongoing) LEAP. 

From a broader perspective, LEAP-GWU-2015 established an international network of centrifuge and computational modelers and a formal protocol for the validation of simulation tools of soil liquefaction. The international collaboration is essential to the success of LEAP as it leverages the financial burden of the associated extensive experimental programs.   Validation of soil liquefaction simulation tools will provide engineers and decision makers with a realistic assessment of the associated capabilities and limitations and will ultimately enable more efficient design and maintenance of the civil infrastructure.  LEAP-GWU-2015 involved a total of seven graduate students at the three US universities alone (including students from under-represented groups) who were trained in physical and numerical modeling of liquefiable soils.  The results of the P-LEAP experiments and simulations were presented and discussed in a January 2015 workshop at George Washington University. This workshop was attended by the physical and numerical modeler and a number of invited researchers from academia and industry. The results are now being written up for dissemination in a special issue of the Journal of Soil Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering.
